questions.text: During your rural service, a patient arrives at the OPD with hypopigmented lesions on his trunk and back. A Wood’s lamp examination of the lesions shows yellow fluorescence, and scales become prominent when the lesion is scratched with nails. Which of the following organisms causes this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Malassezia furfur

Explanation:

The condition described is Pityriasis Versicolor, also known as Tinea Versicolor. The term "tinea" is a misnomer, as this infection is caused by the Malassezia species (including M. globosa, M. sympodialis, and M. furfur), not by dermatophytes like Microsporum or Trichophyton.

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules: Most commonly hypopigmentation due to the fungus's production of Azelaic Acid or Carboxylic Acid, found in the trunk, back, and chest.
  • Lesions are often covered with fine “branny” scales, which are accentuated upon scraping; this sign is called the Besnier Sign or the Coup De Angle Sign.

Examination Findings:

  • Wood's Lamp Examination: It is typically yellow or gold in color, attributed to the presence of porphyrins produced by Malassezia species.
  • KOH Preparation: "Spaghetti and meatball" aka “Banana and Grapes” appearance.

Treatment:

  • Topical Antifungal Agents such as ketoconazole cream or shampoo, selenium sulfide lotion, or ciclopirox olamine solution are used as first-line treatment.
  • Oral Terbinafine and Griseofulvin do not help in the treatment of Tinea.


Microsporum audouinii (Option B)

Trichophyton rubrum (Option C)

 Epidermophyton floccosum (Option D)

The three fungi mentioned above are dermatophytic fungi that do not cause ptyriasis versicolor; they cause tinea in various body parts, as described below.

 

 

Microsporum audouinii

Trichophyton rubrum

Epidermophyton floccosum

    (scalp)

questions.text: A 67-year-old actress, diagnosed with HIV 20 years ago, presents to your OPD with complaints of itching and flaking on her eyelids and scalp. The examination findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is not caused by the organism responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Piedra

Explanation: 

  • The given clinical scenario describes Seborrheic Dermatitis caused by the Malessezia (globosa [Most common] and furfur species) fungus. 
  • It is characterised by erythematous, greasy, and scaly lesions, often accompanied by itching and discomfort, in immunocompromised patients, as described in the image above.
  • Primarily affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp, face, and upper trunk.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis is also associated with other conditions, such as Parkinson's disease and immunosuppression.
  • Treatment involves topical antifungal agents, such as ketoconazole or ciclopirox.
  • Malessezia is known to cause folliculitis, Seborrheic dermatitis, dandruff, and confluent reticulate papillomatosis.

On the other hand, piedra is a fungal infection of the hair shaft caused by fungi of the genus Trichosporon (white piedra) and piedra (black piedra).


Folliculitis (Option A): Malassezia can lead to folliculitis, particularly pityrosporum folliculitis. It typically presents with erythematous papules or pustules centred around hair follicles, which may be tender or pruritic.

 

Dandruff (Option B) also known as pityriasis capitis or seborrheic dermatitis of the scalp, is commonly associated with Malassezia spp., the same organism implicated in the patient's symptoms.

Confluent Reticulate Papillomatosis (CRP) (Option C), also known as Gougerot-Carteaud syndrome, is a rare dermatosis characterised by brown, reticulated papules typically affecting the neck and upper trunk. Malassezia spp is known to be the organism implicated in CRP.

questions.text:
On your annual visit to the local orphanage in farmland to celebrate your birthday, you notice a 5-year-old boy crying due to a painful, boggy swelling on his scalp, shown in the image below. Multiple other boys in the orphanage also have areas of patchy, scaly hair loss. Which of the following is the causative organism of this patient’s findings?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trichophyton Verrucosum

Explanation:

  • The condition described is most likely a kerion, a type of inflammatory tinea capitis (scalp ringworm) caused by Trichophyton verrucosum.
  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that predominantly affects children.
  • Kerion presents with symptoms, including patchy hair loss, scaling, and, in some cases, a painful, boggy swelling.
  • The characteristic feature of kerion is its inflammatory nature, with erythematous, tender nodules commonly oozing pus
  • It is often encountered in agricultural settings where there is exposure to infected animals, particularly cattle.

 

Examination Findings

  • KOH examination: Presence of branching hyphae.
  • Wood's lamp examination: No specific findings.
  • The inflammatory nature of kerion distinguishes it from other fungal infections.

In severe cases of tinea capitis presenting as a kerion, both KOH mounts and fungal cultures can sometimes yield negative results. This is due to the body's robust immune response and inflammation, which can damage or kill the fungal elements, making them less likely to be detected in diagnostic tests.

Treatment:

  • Systemic Antifungal therapy: Oral antifungal medications such as Griseofulvin (Drug of choice) and terbinafine are the treatments of choice.
  • Topical Antifungal Therapy: Topical antifungal agents, such as ketoconazole or ciclopirox, to address recurrence
  • Antibiotics: In cases of secondary bacterial infection, antibiotics may be necessary to treat bacterial superinfection and reduce inflammation

 

Fungal infections of the scalp are classified as follows:

Tinea schoenleinii (Option A), also known as favus, typically presents with thick, yellow, cup-shaped crusts known as scutula rather than painful, boggy swellings as seen in Kerion. It exhibits green fluorescence on Wood's lamp.


Microsporum canis (Option C) often presents as an itchy “grey patch” associated with hair loss. Wood's lamp examination may reveal fluorescent hairs in some cases. Exophytic growth is seen in microsporium.


Trichophyton concentricum (Option D) is associated with tinea corporis, a superficial fungal infection of the body. Endophytic growth is seen in trichophyton.

questions.text: During a health check-up in a tropical coastal region, a 30-year-old patient presents with a well-demarcated, non-pruritic, dark brown macule on their palm. The lesion has gradually increased in size over the past few months. There is no associated pain or scaling. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tinea nigra

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests tinea nigra. Tinea nigra is a painless, superficial fungal infection primarily affecting the palms and is characterized by darkly pigmented, flat, non-scaly patches.

Tinea nigra:

  • Superficial fungal infection of the skin caused by the fungus Hortaea werneckii (formerly known as Exophiala werneckii).
  • Pathology: Thickening of stratum corneum (in which hyphae are present) and minimal inflammation of the dermis.
  • Features:
    • Asymptomatic, macular, sharply defined and non-scaly lesions.
    • The most distinctive feature is the brown or black, resembling a silver nitrate stain.
    • Areas affected: Palms (M/C), soles, neck, and trunk.
  • Microscopy with a KOH mount shows pigmented filaments with conidia, abundant brown, branched, closely septate hyphae up to 5 μm in diameter, and elongated budding cells.

  • Treatment: It is usually treated with topical antifungal agents. The most commonly used topical agents include azoles (clotrimazole or ketoconazole) or allylamines (terbinafine).

 

Melanocytic nevus (Option A): A melanocytic nevus is a benign growth of melanocytes, typically presenting as a brown or tan mole with well-defined borders, and don’t typically show the gradual increase in size described here without other features like irregular borders or color variation.

Dermatofibroma (Option B): Dermatofibromas are usually small, firm, brown or tan nodules, not macules, and they typically occur on the limbs rather than the palms.

 

Lichen planus (Option D): Lichen planus typically presents with purplish, flat-topped papules and often involves the wrists, shins, or mucous membranes.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old boy comes to your OPD complaining of an itchy rash over his forearm for the past 8 months. He gives history of unsupervised use of over the counter creams ,but it has only gotten worse after short-lived improvements. An image of the lesion is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tinea Incognito

Explanation:

  • The lesion depicted in the image shows an irregular, erythematous, scaly plaque without central clearing, lack of annularity and indistinct border of the lesions which is characteristic of tinea incognito.
  • The prolonged use of topical corticosteroids can mask typical features of tinea, resulting in misdiagnosis and worsening of the condition.
  • In this case, the patient's history of visiting multiple local "healing clinics" that probably used local steroid ointments and the lesion worsening after initial improvement suggest a diagnosis of tinea incognito.

 

Causative Organisms: Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton species.

Treatment:

  • Like other tinea infections, the treatment for T. incognito involves first discontinuing corticosteroid medication, followed by the use of topical antifungals such as azoles (e.g., clotrimazole, ketoconazole) or allylamines (e.g., terbinafine).
  • Additionally, management of secondary bacterial or fungal infections, if present, may be necessary.
  • Patients should be educated about the appropriate use of topical corticosteroids

Tinea manuum (Option A) is a dermatophyte infection of the hands, typically presenting with erythematous, scaly lesions on the palms and interdigital spaces.

Tinea profunda (Option C) is a rare deep dermatophyte infection that involves invasion of the hair follicles and surrounding dermis, resulting in boggy nodules and abscess formation.

Tinea corporis (Option D) is a dermatophyte infection affecting the trunk, limbs, or face, characterised by annular, erythematous lesions with central clearing and an active border.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus presents to the dermatology clinic with discoloured nails. The examination findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Distal Lateral Subungual Onychomycosis

 

Explanation:

  • Distal Lateral Subungual Onychomycosis is the most common type of fungal infection of the toenail (Onymychosis) or Tinea Unguium.

Clinically, onychomycosis presents with various manifestations, including

  • Discoloration of the nails (yellow, brown, or white)
  • Thickening of the nail plate
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis (build-up of keratin debris under the nail)
  • Onycholysis (separation of the nail plate from the nail bed)
  • Nail dystrophy (deformation of the nail)

Diagnosis: Typically involves microscopic examination using KOH and fungal culture of nail clippings.

Treatment:

  • Oral antifungals such as terbinafine and itraconazole are often preferred.
  • Nail lacquers such as ciclopirox (applied daily), olamine and amirolfine (applied weekly) are also used as topical agents to treat onychomycosis.

The table below describes the types of onychomycosis

Distal lateral subungual onychomycosis
  • Most common
  • Primarily affecting the distal & lateral portions of the nail.

Proximal subungual onychomycosis
  • Seen in individuals with HIV.
  • Affects the proximal portion of the nail plate.

Superficial white onychomycosis

Characterized by the presence of white, crumbly material on the surface of the nail, which can be easily scrapped off

Total dystrophic onychomycosis

Characterized by extensive involvement of the nail plate, leading to complete destruction & deformity of the nail

 

 

Paronychia (Option B) refers to an infection of the soft tissues surrounding the nail, often presenting with erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the nail folds.

 

Nail Psoriasis (Option C) is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the nails, characterised by pitting, subungual hyperkeratosis, and oil drop discolouration.

  • Absence of salmon pink sign and skin plaques can be used to differentiate from psoriasis

Onychogryphosis (Option D), also known as ram's horn nails, is a condition characterised by abnormal thickening and curvature of the nails, typically affecting the toenails, most commonly caused by improper footwear, trauma, ichthyosis, psoriasis and fungal infections

questions.text: A student from a hostel dormitory visits you with complaints of narrow nodules on her hair shafts. On examination, you find that these nodules are loosely attached to the surface of the hair, white in colour and soft in consistency. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trichosporon beigelii

Explanation:

  • The condition described, characterised by narrow, soft, white nodules loosely attached to the hair shafts, is consistent with a diagnosis of White Piedra caused by Trichosporon beigelii.
  • The differences between black and white piedra are given in the table below:
 

White Piedra

Black Piedra

Etiology

Trichosporon beigelii

Piedra horteii

Consistency

Soft

Hard, gritty

Attachment to the hair shaft

Loosely attached

Tightly attached

Location

All hair-bearing areas

Over the scalp
Images 

 

 

 

Piedra horteii (Option A): As described above, Piedraia hortae causes black piedra, characterised by hard, dark nodules on the hair shafts.


Trichosporon cutaneum (Option C): Associated with skin infections and other superficial infections.


Trichophyton violaceum (Option D): This dermatophyte fungus causes tinea infections of the skin and nails and may rarely affect the hair shaft.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old lady with diabetes comes to your OPD complaining of itching under her breasts. On examination, you see multiple erythematous, tender patches on the inferior surface of both breasts with multiple satellite lesions as shown in the image below. What is the causative organism and the diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candida albicans (Intertrigo)

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of multiple erythematous, tender patches on the inferior surface of both breasts with multiple satellite lesions is highly indicative of intertrigo, a type of cutaneous candidiasis.

Candida intertrigo (Flexural candidiasis):

  • Sites involved:
    • Between genital folds, groin & buttocks
    • Armpits
    • Inframammary folds (large & pendulous breasts)
    • Under overhanging abdominal folds
    • Umbilicus
    • Webspace of toes & fingers.
  • As the condition develops, it spreads beyond the area of contact, usually developing the typical features of candidiasis: a fringed, irregular edge, subcorneal pustules rupturing to give tiny erosions, and further peeling of the stratum corneum.
  • Satellite lesions, pustular or papular, are classic.
  • Soreness and itching, which may be intense on occasion, are usual.
  • When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are involved, there is usually marked maceration along with a thick, white, horny layer.

.

 

Other cutaneous candidiasis:

  • Paronychia and onychomycosis.
  • Diaper candidiasis.
  • Perianal candidiasis.
  • Erosio interdigitalis blastomycetica (affects webs and toes).
  • Generalized disseminated cutaneous candidiasis (in infants).

Candida albicans:

  • The most common & most pathogenic species of candida infecting humans thrive in warm & moist areas.
  • Risk factors: Diabetes mellitus, immunocompromised state, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pregnancy, obesity, a ity, diet high in sugars, corticosteroids, and underlying medical conditions.
  • Treatment:
    • Topical antifungal creams or ointments such as clotrimazole, miconazole, or nystatin
    • For more severe or recurrent infections, oral antifungal medications like fluconazole, itraconazole, or ketoconazole may be prescribed.

 

Trichophyton Circinata (Tinea) (Option B) causes dermatophyte infections that present as ring-shaped, circular patches on the skin. The lesions often have a clear central area with scaly, red edges.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Erysipelas) (Option C):

  • Presents with well-demarcated, erythematous, raised lesions with a fiery red appearance.
  • It typically affects the face and extremities.

Malassezia furfur (Pityriasis versicolor) (Option D): Pityriasis versicolor, caused by Malassezia furfur, presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented patches on the skin, typically on the trunk, neck, and upper arms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old uncircumcised male patient with a T-cell deficiency presents to your outpatient clinic. On examination,  a frayed appearance and the presence of superficial pustules on the penis is noted. A KOH examination reveals the following findings. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oral Fluconazole

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a frayed appearance, superficial pustules, and the presence of pseudohyphae on KOH examination is indicative of Balanitis due to Candida infection.

Oral fluconazole is preferred for treating Candida infections involving the genital area due to its systemic action and effectiveness in eradicating the fungal infection in immunocompromised individuals.

Microscopic tests for the diagnosis of candidal infection:

  • KOH Preparation: Characteristic findings include oval-shaped budding yeast cells and elongated pseudohyphae (elongated cells that are not separated from each other).
  • Candida exhibits the yeast form in the human body (approximately 37°C or 98.6°F) and the hyphal form in higher temperatures (98.6-107.6°F).
  • Culture: On Sabourad's Dextrose agar (SDA), Candida colonies appear creamy to white and smooth, often with a yeast-like or pasty texture.
  • Germ Tube Test:
    • It is a diagnostic test used to differentiate Candida albicans from other Candida species.
    • It involves incubating yeast cells in human or animal serum at 37°C for 2-3 hours.
    • Positive germ tube formation, characterised by the emergence of a hyphal projection (germ tube) from the yeast cell, is typically observed with Candida albicans.

 

Local application of nystatin gel (Option A): Nystatin is an antifungal agent effective against Candida, commonly used to treat oral thrush and vulvovaginal candidiasis. However, its local application may not be adequate for treating balanitis, particularly if the infection is extensive or involves deeper tissue layers. 


Local application of terbinafine ointment (Option C): Terbinafine is primarily used to treat dermatophyte infections, such as tinea corporis or tinea cruris, and is ineffective against Candida species.


Oral griseofulvin (Option D) – Ineffective against Candida infections as it primarily targets dermatophyte fungi by inhibiting microtubule function.

questions.text: A 40-year-old heroin and nicotine abuser with a 20-year history of untreated HIV comes to your community clinic complaining of a white patch on his tongue. You are unable to scrape the lesion off, and examination findings are given in the image below. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Initiate Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART)

Explanation:

  • The image above describing a white plaque on the tongue, resembling cottage cheese in an immunocompromised patient, is suggestive of chronic plaque/ leukoplakia candidiasis
  • In individuals with untreated HIV/AIDS, oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection.
  • Management of HIV/AIDS involves initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART) as the primary intervention.
  • Treatment with nystatin gargles, oral fluconazole, and oral ketoconazole- the various treatments for oral candidiasis can be initiated after ART has been started.

Oral Thrush can present as:

 

Red Lesions

White Lesions

Acute Lesions

Antibiotic sore mouth (due to usage of antibiotics)

Pseudomembranous Thrush (can be scraped off)

Chronic Lesions

Chronic Erythematous/ Denture Stomatitis

Chronic Plaque/ leukoplakia (cannot be scraped off)

 

Tongue biopsy (Option A): While biopsy may be considered if the diagnosis is uncertain or if premalignant lesions (submucal fibrosis, erythroleukoplakia, etc) are suspected, the priority, in this case, is to address the underlying HIV infection with ART.


Nystatin gargle and Oral Fluconazole (Option B) are antifungal agents that may be used for oral candidiasis, but it is not the first-line treatment in individuals with untreated HIV/AIDS.


Topical corticosteroid therapy (Option D): Corticosteroids are contraindicated in oral candidiasis as they can exacerbate fungal infections by suppressing the immune response.

questions.text: Which pattern is most likely to be observed in the hair perforation test result of Trichophyton mentagrophytes infection?

choices.text: Wedge-shaped hair perforations along the hair shaft
Circular perforations inside the hair shaft
Parallel perforations on either side of the hair shaft

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wedge Shaped Perforations along the hair shaft

Explanation:

The hair perforation test is used to identify species of Trichophyton mentagrophytes from other dermatophytes such as Trichophyton rubrum. Trichophyton causes characteristic wedge-shaped perforations along the hair shaft, as shown in the image below; this is called a positive perforation test.

Steps with hair perforation test:

  • A strand of blonde, autoclaved hair is placed in water in a vial and incubated at room temperature.
  • It is then inoculated with the test fungus.
  • Individual hair is removed at intervals of up to 4 weeks and examined microscopically in lactophenol cotton blue.
  • Isolates of T. mentagrophytes produce marked localised areas of pitting and erosion.
  • Isolates of T. rubrum (a more common cause of tinea) do not produce marked pitting or erosion.

Absence of hair perforation (Option A) – Seen in Trichophyton rubrum, which does not produce significant hair perforations, unlike T. mentagrophytes.


Circular perforations inside the hair shaft (Option C) – More characteristic of Trichophyton verrucosum, which forms internal perforations instead of wedge-shaped indentations.


Parallel perforations on either side of the hair shaft (Option D) – Not a recognized pattern in dermatophyte infections

questions.text:
At your community medicine posting, a farmer arrives complaining of multiple nodules over his right leg after being pricked by a thistle. Examination findings are given in the image below. What would you expect to find on a microscopic examination of tissue from one of his lesions?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asteroid Bodies

Explanation:

The patient’s presentation, along with the linear distribution of nodules, is suggestive of sporotrichosis/ Rose Gardner’s disease caused by Sporothrix schenckii.

  • It is a Subcutaneous fungal infection that typically occurs after the fungus is traumatically inoculated into the skin, often through thorn pricks, splinters, or scratches from contaminated plant materials.
  • Enzymes secreted by fungus, such as serine & aspartate proteinases help in local invasion.
  • Sporothrix schenckii has a tendency to spread along lymphatics.
  • Risk factors: Walking barefoot, farmers & gardeners.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Incubation period: 3 weeks
    • Types:

Lympho-cutaneous
  • M/C type (80%)
  • Painless modulo-ulcerative lesions along the lymphatics.
  • Lymph nodes can become enlarged, suppurative & indurated and have cord-like feeling on palpation.

Osteoarticular

  • Seen in alcoholics.

Pulmonary
  • Can be seen in underlying COPD.

Disseminated
  • Seen in immunocompromised patients.

Fixed cutaneous
  • Single nodule, less progressive & not spread by lymphatics.
  • Laboratory diagnosis:
    • KOH mount: Elongated yeast cells of 3-5 𝜇m in diameter (low sensitivity).
    • Histopathological staining with methenamine silver reveals cigar-shaped asteroid bodies comprising a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating eosinophilic extensions composed of antigen-antibody complexes. This eosinophilic halo is known as the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.
    • ​​​​​​​Culture is the most definitive test for diagnosis.

The image below shows the culture of S. schenckii:

The image below shows the asteroid body and Splendour Hoeppli phenomenon:

Treatment of Sporotrichosis:

  • Itraconazole is the drug of choice for all forms except disseminated sporotrichosis.
  • Amphotericin B is the preferred treatment for disseminated sporotrichosis.
  • Potassium iodide can also be used.

 

Black Granules (Option B) are classically associated with mycetoma/ Madura foot, caused by the organism M. mycetomatis. It can also be caused by the Actinomycetes bacteria, where there is the formation of yellow/ sulphur granules and discharging sinuses.

Madura foot:

Histopathology of Actinomycotic mycetoma:

Muriform bodies (Option C) are seen in chromoblastomycosis, which also occurs in farmers with a history of thorn or thistle pricks. It shows slow-growing, polymorphic, verrucous (m/c type) lesions and sclerotic bodies (muriform cells/medlar bodies).

Spherules containing endospores (Option D) are characteristic of coccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection.
